reviewText:
“The world is an awful, uncool place; it should be burned to the ground, and anybody not cool enough destroyed.” This is the somewhat extreme premise of Mango Protocol’s MechaNika. With a basis such as that, one might expect a dark and haunting descent-into-madness story full of Lovecraftian insanity and visuals. In reality, MechaNika stars adorable 7-year-old Nika Allen, a misunderstood child prodigy with plenty of sass who’s tired of living in a world filled with condescending adults. Her solution to this problem is to build a robot of destruction using parts she finds, trades for, and creates herself at home and around town, in a short point-and-click adventure that seems to suffer from a mild case of identity crisis.

If not for its dark theme, it’d be easy to dismiss MechaNika as a kids’ game due to its simple art style resembling a Saturday morning cartoon and its nursery-style soundtrack. But while it features a young anti-hero, the actual subject matter is directed quite purposely toward an adult audience. Nika must deal with her ostracism from society: her parents downright ignore her, her teachers are wrapped up in themselves, and most of her peers don’t relate to her. There are deeper issues at play here, like a reference to her parents having had a failed pregnancy some time ago, possibly causing them to retreat into themselves, and Nika’s grandparents becoming recently estranged from each other.

But these things are really just window-dressing – MechaNika doesn’t attempt to delve into Nika’s mind to analyze her. Instead, the game passes itself off as a whimsical dark comedy. It maintains a silly tone throughout, even though Nika herself treats her dilemma seriously. The local school, where the game begins, is surrounded by an electrified fence to contain the students, Nika encounters an aging cosplayer on the street who flexes his glutes for the public’s pleasure, and at one point Nika dresses up as her grandmother, then walks around and interacts with others as she imagines a senior citizen would.

But there are other times when MechaNika tries too hard to be edgy, like when Nika has to supply a homeless man who lives in a cave outside of town with pornography to get an item. But the moment that really drove the point home was when her grandmother (out of the blue) makes some very graphic references concerning her grandfather engaging in bestiality. Injecting moments of South Park into an otherwise playful game just didn’t quite jibe for me, though tastes may of course differ.

The game’s visuals, while also a little off-putting at first, grew on me after a short while, especially the way Nika narrows her eyes and makes faces when people annoy her – it’s just cute coming from a child her age. MechaNika has a hand-drawn look, with thick outlines, caricatured cartoon townspeople, and basic environments. Animation is just as simple – again, think budget cartoons – with most characters simply going through a few choppy frames over and over again. Nika herself, however, is fully animated. Pre- and post-game cinematics are simply still frames with text boxes, all very rudimentary but sufficient.

There are no voice-overs. All dialog is presented via comic book-style speech bubbles and text boxes, for which the developers have included a more basic font if the preset cursive doesn’t appeal to you. Music is hit-and-miss. For the most part, the childish nature of the graphics is present in the music as well. The couple of tunes you’ll hear run the gamut from pleasant to dull, and there’s only a handful of different tracks – around a half dozen or so – to hear. Ultimately, neither the graphics nor the music do much to make the game stand out in the end.

Though I felt a little iffy about MechaNika’s comedic bent, its actual gameplay works flawlessly and left me satisfied, despite its short duration. Early on, you are presented with a blueprint of items that Nika requires to build her robot, and it’s up to you to scour the town to get what’s needed. The blueprints don’t always spell out what items you need to look for, however. About half the items only provide descriptions such as “something that can be launched” or “something that can propel big objects”. It’s up to you to figure out what item matches best, then assign that item from the inventory to the blueprint, a formula that offers quick fixes of success as the blueprint rapidly fills up.

It’s pretty easy to find an appliance in your house that will supply you with a microwave transmitter, but having the right tools for the job and then getting Nika’s mom out of the room to let her work in peace are a different matter. Traditional lateral thinking and correct inventory item use are required, though most puzzles are self-evident and the level of challenge fairly low. Once all pieces are acquired, you’ll gain access to Nika’s secret lab for the final steps of building her death machine.

The inventory is accessed by clicking on Nika, bringing up a display of her backpack on-screen. All inventory items, the blueprints and a save feature are incorporated as elements of the backpack. Nika even carries around a little metal flask, filled with a concoction of cognac and cocoa. Imbibing a swig of this mixture causes her to become a little tipsy, freeing her “thought processes”. Interacting with the rest of the world is done by simply clicking on items or people; if Nika can interact in any way, icons appear on-screen, like “talk” or “pick up”, etc. When Nika is in conversation with somebody, the speech bubble will display only one dialog option at a time, even though multiple topics are usually available.

As satisfying as the shopping list-style point-and-click gameplay is, I never found myself truly immersed in Mango Protocol’s “Psychotic” universe, as it’s called, which seems to be a meta world in which various stories are meant to take place. MechaNika itself ends on a cliffhanger, hinting at possible plans for future installments. However, the world is a bit too limited, with only a handful of places to go and too few characters to interact with, and then only on a superficial level. Players will find lots of references to other games, movies, and general pop culture in MechaNika, like Ninja Turtles, Halo, and Alien, but while the the world is certainly quirky, it is far removed from being truly “psychotic”.

Humor is a subjective thing, and others may like MechaNika’s dark comedy where it fell flat for me, so I’m willing to look past that for the most part. I did like the gameplay itself, as straightforward as it is. But the music could certainly do with more variety, and most players will have seen and done everything there is in less than two hours. The reason it’s so short is that the big payoff promised from the beginning is pushed to a sequel, as the game ends abruptly just as Nika completes her robot. Really MechaNika seems more like an introduction to the world, a first act rather than a standalone game that ends up leaving a more tepid impression than by rights it should have if allowed to develop fully.

reviewText:
Nika Allen is a  seven year old child genius in world that she despises. Being a genius she has the capability to do what we can't do when we are disillusioned about the way we live: Destroy it if course! I thought children were supposed to be untouched by the cynicism and bitterness we feel about the world today from our teenage years...

This is a point and click game where you will help sweet little Nika gather the items she needs. In case you miss this if you double click on Nika she will run like her life depended on it. The art is not anything to write home about. Despite the simple, drawn childlike style this is a game designed with adults in mind. In fact the choice of art style is good choice for MechaNika because it lightens the dark undertones and humour in the game. Give this plot to another developer and we would be reviewing a horror game not a short point and click.

The strength of this game is its dark humour dialogue. The references to subjects such as gaming and anime will give the player a chuckle. I would like to think there is some deeper meaning to this game as it touches lightly on the themes such as addiction. Maybe it's a commentary on the perception that the developer sees the world he lives in.
This game is the first by Mango Protocol and was voted through Greenlight. I missed this one but based on this game I will put my vote in for the next one they produce. This game is worth your time and money, especially if you like point and click games.
voteText: 20 of 21 people (95%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I was intrigued to play this, as my hope was that it would be like Willy Beamish with a dark, clever sense of humour. The trailer showed a teacher ignoring her young students - who drink booze out of hip flasks - as she played games on her cellphone. I was optimistic.

Sadly, all of this over-the-top excess is for nought. Extreme vulgarity for its own sake doesn't ring out as anything but cheap shock, and I'm afraid this is all MechaNika has to offer.

If all it takes to entertain you is that somebody '♥♥♥♥s goats' devoid of any context or connection to anything within the game, then by all means: Have a great time. The art, music and production elements are all perfectly fine. The puzzles are very easy, and guidance is always available in-game.

Just don't go into it expecting something that uses its own crassness in any kind of interesting way.
voteText: 65 of 102 people (64%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
MechaNika is a short, but quite good and entertaining point & click adventure. It looks like a game made for children, with its simple yet charming visuals, but is definitely aimed at adults, with some quite twisted and dark humour in it.

Nika is a young, intelligent girl, frustrated by the world around her. So she plans the invention of MechaNika, a giant robot with which she wants to take revenge on the whole world and destroy everything that is not awesome. Help her assemble all necessary parts and get to see yourself all of those hilarious things not awesome. Meet hobos with cats in their beards, male pro*stitutes and Martyr Pig, who sacrificed itself to show us how good sausages are, amongst other unusual characters.

Controls are simple, as you would expect from a point & click adventure game, puzzles are logical and not too easy at times. The humour is often quite black and great. Graphics sometimes look a bit amateurish, but have a distinct and likeable style. The music is not outstanding, but still quite good.

The only downsides, if you want to call them downsides, are that the game is very short indeed and options are more or less non-existent. It's a mobile port with low resolution, but with the choice of style for the graphics, it doesn't matter much.

Considering its length, pick it up in a decent sale for a price tag that reflects the mobile price. Having said that, it is still worth the normal, already quite low price. If you are into point & click adventures, odds are you are going to enjoy it. Probably a lot.

reviewText:
This is a cute and fun little game. Don't be fooled by its innocent art style, though, it's quite dark and intended for a mature audience. You got a 7 year old whose secret concoction is cognac and coacoa, who is basically invisible to her dysfunctional family.

You play as Nika, a little girl who is bored and tired of school, and basically the whole world. She devises a plan to create MechaNika--possible a super mech that she can use to purge the world of things that are not awesome. I'm not very far in the game, but I guess that's where it's headed.

The puzzles are very easy, you can collect items for her project quite easily. This is a fun and relaxing game to play to squeeze the last bit of your intellect after a long day at work, and not a game for intensely cryptic puzzles. The story and dialogue are fun and cute, and I look forward to more games from the Psychotic's world.

reviewText:
MechaNika is a funny point & click, where you play a seven year old girl that plans to destroy the world.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fdLmzTmphYA
It's a very simple game to play, but the gameplay isn't the attraction. It's the funny dialogue, and characters.

Nika tends to be smarter than everyone around her, so when interacting with other people, you get the option to mess with them, or question them, and it gets pretty humorous.
There's a girl who wears an eyepatch and calls herself pirate girl, and a kid in the playground that makes a living from being a dealer. As in, weapons dealer. Yes, the game has some funny darker stuff like this too.

The game's art style looks really cute, and isn't ruined by any HUD. You access your inventory and menus by clicking on the character, so the game looks pretty clean. If you get stuck, you can drink fro her flask, containing a special concoction. She'll give a vague enough hint for the game to still be fun incase you're really stumped. It's a nice option to have.

The music is really great as well. It adds to the atmosphere in different places.

Overall, it's a fun, and very cheap game. So if you're a fan of point & clicks or this type of humor, check it out!
voteText: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
overallMechaNika feels very fresh. It's cute, twisted, lighthearted and funny. I struggle to remember the last time an adventure game was this cool. The mischievous Nika with her grand but misguided ambitions reminds me of being a kid again, while the adult references and quirky humour make it entertaining.

artThe cartoony world is rich with cute, expressively animated characters, which plays great against the purposefully functional backgrounds. A nice touch is the addition of several short, graphic novel inspired cutscenes.

writingWhile it's frequently twisted and filled with adult themes, the playful, lighthearted tone makes these parts funny, albeit a bit crude at times.

caveatsonly 2-3 hours long; not even long enough to collect the drop cards.
fairly easy puzzles
vulgar humour in sections
weird inventory interface and some non-standard exits
no voice acting
story is arguably a cliffhanger (but given the tone, I didn't see it this way).

reviewText:
Short, lovely and weird, very weird.

Nika is a 7 year old girl who plans on destroying the world as we know it due to the fact that nobody gets her. And that's it, nothing more nothing less. We play as Nika in her crusade to find the items she needs to fulfill her dreams and build the ultimate machine, MechaNika, that she will use to, well, destroy us.

Art style is cute as in very cute but don't let that fool you this isn't a game for little kids, it contains some mature dialogs and scenes that would make your kid ask you some questions you don't want them asking you yet.

Pros.
Art style.
References to games and TV shows (Easter eggs)
BGM
Gameplay (really nice thinking material here)
Achievements and trading cards

Cons.
Short (like 5 mins over 2 hours, that's the time it took me to finish it and get all achievements)

Overall 9/10. I got it in a bundle and though I recommend it, i don't do it a full price.

reviewText:
Mechanika is a point and click adventure game about a girl who basically hates everyone. (Except for some other girl who ummm.... does some weird stuff... I'm not going to spoil it here.) The artstyle of the game is very simple and crude, yet charming in its own way. There were a good amount of humorous scenarios and I can definitely say that I enjoyed my time playing through Nika's story. If you are a fan of dark humor, you will be very pleased with this game since it is littered with dark humor.

Overall, the story is nice, the artstyle is charming, and the humor is dark. A perfect combination for me.

However, there is one big con. It's a pretty short game. How short is it? Well I completely beat the game and got every single achievement within 3 hours. And since I was taking my time to play through the game and read everything, it could probably be beaten in even less time very easily.

So if you are an absolute diehard fan of point and click adventure games, dark humor, and hand-drawn visuals, then this game is/should be perfect for you! If you aren't a fan of either of these things, but are still interested in playing, look out for bundles or sales and pick it up then.

reviewText: MechNika is a Point&Click about a little girl that wants to destroy the world. The game has an interesting plot, unique characters, and a handdrawn art style. Also the music in this game is actually pretty good too. The tone of the story is a little bit dark but definitely has alot of humor. The game is only $3.99, but it should be said that the game is only 2-4 hours, and the ending is underwhelming. reviewText: I've found myself checking this game's store page off and on for a few months now, and I originally wanted it because A) it was a point-and-click, and B) because it looked very cute, silly, and lighthearted in general. I had not gone through all of the screenshots on the store page, and not even two minutes into the game, I realized that I was absolutely wrong.\nThe game, while full of cute graphics and seemingly-charming themes, is riddled with dark hurmor, yet maintains a well-put-together story.\nWhile some of the puzzles' solutions may not have been as clear as they could have been at times, it's not frustratingly unclear. All in all, I would recommend the game based on the experience I had.

reviewText:
An inexpensive and entertaining point and click puzzle game where you assist a 7 year old girl with her plans for total world domination. The game is also fairly short, which saves it from overstaying its welcome. The humor is dark (in a good way) in most of the game, though it ventures now and then into cheap gutter humor in a way that is less than endearing.

Pros:
* Accurately depicts school life
* Finally a game that provides a positive portrayal of carnivorism
* A proactive protagonist who is genuinely committed to solving the problems of the modern world instead of whining about them
* The way the art style is done adds a lot of character to the game

Cons:
* Occasional bouts of gutter humor (the whole ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sequence - really?)
* Creators appearing in their own world to talk about how awesome they are
* Puzzles aren't too complicated (this may or may not be a con)

It should also be noted that like most humor, your level of tolerance is going to vary spectacularly.
A nice, but rather short game with a sweet, only slightly disturbing lead character.\nCompletely worth the price.

MechaNika is like somebody took a regular Point & Click Adventure and removed all the bits that weren't fun. It's a concentrated, 90 minute game that is interesting and enjoyable.

There are some downsides: It's so short that I was able to finish it before I had even earned 1 trading card, and I've now 100%'d it but still have 4 trading cards left to get. Also, the text speed and walking speed are quite slow, which gets quite frustrating.

If you like point & click adventure games, even though it's short, MechaNika is definitely worth its $2 sale price.

MechaNika follows a little girl in her quest to engineer her way to a better future. It's a short game, with your standard point&click adventure gameplay. It's not particularly difficult, but it does excel in the dark humour department.

You might be fooled by the graphic style into thinking this is a game aimed at children. This is not a very good assumption. The game covers some adult themes <violence, stillborn children, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s> , with dialog to match appropriately, which paints some darker themes in a funny light.

Overall good art, good music, funny dialogue, simple gameplay, and it's short.

Okay so this is a fun game, but there should really be an age limit on this one, it's really not for kids, even though the style and the age of the main character suggests it is. Personally I don't have a problem with this, I actually bought this game because of the reviews so I knew what I was getting, but I wouldn't want my little sister to bump into this game.

EDIT: just warning everyone that my first playthrough took me a little over two hours. Unlocking leftover achievements took me a little under an hour, so I got about 3 hours of gameplay out of this. A lot of the doors you're hoping to open later on remain closed throughout the game.
I still recommend it, but maybe not at full price.
It may look cute but it has a very dark story and is intended for adults.  Fun point and click game.

A nice point and click adventure, both cute and disturbing. The puzzles aren't ridiculous, but on the other hand it's all rather simple. Took me under two hours to finish the game 100%, and I wasn't particularly fast. So if you want to spend a good couple hours and you like the design you see in the preview, you should get this. If you're looking for something long or difficult, seek elsewhere.
So. All in all. This game was well worth the play. It's great, fun style to look at, and I didn't run into any issues.\n\nAgatha is love, agatha is life.
Hilarious af\nI love this game definately worth every penny\npretty much my life as a whole this game xDD

MechaNika is like somebody took a regular Point & Click Adventure and removed all the bits that weren't fun. It's a concentrated, 90 minute game that is interesting and enjoyable.

There are some downsides: It's so short that I was able to finish it before I had even earned 1 trading card, and I've now 100%'d it but still have 4 trading cards left to get. Also, the text speed and walking speed are quite slow, which gets quite frustrating.

If you like point & click adventure games, even though it's short, MechaNika is definitely worth its $2 sale price.

MechaNika is a game about a bright little girl named Nika who hates her school and most of society. It is a lighthearted point and click adventure of her actions to create a device to reshape the world.

First off, this is definitely NOT a kid’s game. Although the game looks very child friendly and downright cartoonish, there are many situations, characters, and dialogs that are way out there. As mentioned, the graphics are nothing spectacular and can be considered a little lazy at times. Still I think the design fits the story better than high resolution graphics would.

The music in this game is good. There are a couple of really good scores in some of the locations. However, they are all quite short and repeat quickly. Especially if you are going back and forth between different locations a lot.
The controls are pretty standard. You mouse over something and you have options based on the item. You click on Nika and you can access your inventory, setting, or help.

The game is quite short. The first time through it will take a few hours just to figure out how some of the puzzles work and the order of running around. After that, you will be able to complete the game in under an hour. Considering the price of this game and the extra elements, it is definitely worth the price.

The worst things I can really say about the game are. First the start of the game tutorial. Unless I missed something, it is completely un-skippable and is very slow. Once you get out of the classroom, the game speeds up. The second is the main menu and settings.

There are no advanced settings for this game. There are a couple of simple items like changing the resolution, sound, and type of mouse pointer. For me resolution was the hardest thing to work with. I have my PC connected to a 4K TV and it did not want to work with any resolution I clicked through. In the end, I had to manually set my resolution via editing the preferences file. Once I did that, I had no more issues with video.

Ultimately this is a great demented point and click adventure. Hopefully there will be a sequel!

I love mecha nika's game play of searching and figuring out what to do, The characters are all clever and surprising when you see them for the first time (like wow this is here?) Only disapointment I had was the ending, I wish I could have seen the aftermath instead of text or a continued game to see the outcome.

pros: self discovery and unknown achievements making the player work for them


con: a bit too much on your own thinking
Nika's drunk hints do help but not all the time
took long to figure out that I needed to drag bag items onto the list to 'connect' the items there was no instructions about that; only to put finished items through the slot in her room which wasnt even an option.

I'm not a fan of point-and-click adventure games, but I loved MechaNika. It's simultaneously cute, bleak, and funny. It's not flawless, but the graphics and writing are bursting with personality and the gameplay's mostly straightforward. I'm looking forward to the upcoming prequel, Agatha Knife.
9/10 Would convert to Carnivorism again.

This game is everything I expected and more. The sound track and art is great, the interaction and exploring is funny. Overall this game is filled with humor and epicness. This game reminds me of the Point & Click games that I grew up with. The games from websites like Newgrounds and Miniclip. This game is worth more than the price in my opinion. If you like the art style and a simple humorous game, get it.

Here's a video to show you how the game plays:

https://youtu.be/gHpzf5J2_3A
Not for kids, wonderful dark humour and so fricking cute!\n\nPassed in 3.5 hours. Not very long but worth the price twice over imo :)
A flavor of macabre I've never seen before. The ways in which Nika rationalizes her hatred for the world are hilarious, and very relatable.

MechaNika is a short point and click adventure game with a great art style and brilliant sense of dark humour. It is quite short but considering the price, I don't mind the length of the game. The humour in terms of the dialogue and art style is on point and MechaNika manages dark comedy in a more subtle way than most games. An enjoyable game from start to finish, I would recommend MechaNika to anyone who enjoys narratively driven, puzzle solving games.
I am in love with a 7 y old.

reviewText:
Cute and fun! Nice little story, and also inspiring.
The details to the story are very goofy and will make you laugh at a certain point.
Many references are made, especially toward the geek/gaming culture.

Only low point are the various useless interactive objects/people/places. I can not believe there were so many useless things that kept you intrigued, and on the end, turned out to be completly useless for the game, even for the achievements.

Else, it's definitly worth a little 5$ to have a real good for a day.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I thought I'd give this a shot since it was cheap and it looked fairly cute.
I really wished my shot had missed.
I can understand a small kid wanting to destroy the world because she sees it as being unfair and wrong,
But what I can't get is that the whole game's premise is based off of that.
Okay, the game throws in easter eggs and references to other games and the art style is cute,
Yet some of the puzzles are a bit tricky and don't offer any guidance as to how the puzzles are solved.
Sadly, I just couldn't find myself liking the game enough to keep it in my game library.
I suppose it's alright if you want easy achievements and for younger players,
But for me? Sadly I can't reccomend this game to other players.

reviewText:
Average Point and Click Adventure [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]

This is a simple point and click adventure with a couple of easy puzzles. It has some vague references to the nerd community (Pacific Rim, Gundam, Ninja Turtles, Lolitas) and some sort of uninspired black humor.
If not for a couple of events it could be passed for a kid's game.
I finished it in a couple of hours and I didn't like it so much... it is very indie.
There are a lot better point and click adventures out there.

Best played with Keyboard and Mouse
Recommended Buy Price < 3$
Score 6/10

reviewText: There might be an okay game in here somewhere, but the interface is INFURIATING.  I couldn't take it anymore.  Dialog is parceled out in 10 short clips of 10 or so words at a time.  Each one writes out very slowly a word at a time (in a cursive style that's hard to read, a separate annoyance).  To get the whole thing to write out more quickly, press escape, then press escape to get to next short block of text, escape again to get that one to spell out, again, again, again, again.  You're pounding the escape key dozens of times to get through every conversation.  It's unbearable.
voteText: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
As cute as the game looks and starts out, don't be fooled into thinking that this is a game suitable for kids! There are several dark and/or mature subjects that are dealt with in the game. Also, graphic images (yes, even cartoon nudity can be 'raunchy'). I understood the creator's intention of being hilarious and shocking in a game that looks like you'd least suspect it, but playing this when there are people are not around is generally not a good idea. Unless of course you don't mind explaining yourself and the filfth that is on your screen all the time.

The game objective is fairly simple: find items to make the ultimate killing machine! The how is simple as well: get them by talking to people and/or doing this for them. It gets a bit repetative, to be honest. As long as you keep this in mind: your objective is never to open up locked area! You could finish this game very fast. There is ONE place however where all gamers appear to get stuck. Everyone knows what I'm talking about - when you've acquired a certain outfit. Gentle hint: find places to hide in WITHOUT entering a house or building. Good luck with that.

Another major disappointment is the climax that the game reaches. Nika's tension is building when you receive more items over time. You actually find yourself getting excited with her. So what is to expect when she finally manages her objective? Well, nothing much... Whether that is nothing much because Nika's plan is grander in her own mind than put to practise or because the game is just a short little indie plot, I'll leave you to discover that for yourself.

I wouldn't recommend the game. Its settings are a bit too much over-the-topness mixed together. There are so many places that are locked, that you imagine there is a lot (more) to discover, but no...closed is closed (off). Nika is much too gifted to be 6/7 or whatever, but whatever. It is the bratty and ultimate entitlement that I really dislike! There are too many ways to shock people incorporated into the game. Instead of laughing, you will just start raising your eyebrows instead. It is TOO much in very little time, so it just ends up falling flat instead. What a waste...

But, mothers, do not buy this game for your kiddies. They will not only stop believing in Santa Clause, they will find out where meat really does come from and what those scantily dressed ladies at the corner really do. And no, it's not selling candy...

reviewText:
I got the Hidden Gems bundle because I was interested in this game. I've always liked point n click adventure games, as I played a lot of them, such as the Reincarnation series, back in the day on websites like NewGrounds. If you're looking for a long game like Deponia, this isn't it. This is more akin to those previously-mentioned games on NewGrounds and Kongregate.

MechaNika is about a young girl who has a pretty rough life. Your quest is to find parts to destroy everything she hates, basically. If you get stuck, you can get wasted and she'll give you a hint. There's a lot of fun little quirks in the game that you can interact with, that may or may not actually impact the story. You can complete most of it in any order you please.

I got it for $2.99 and I feel it was worth my money. If you want a more complete story, you might wait until MangoProtocol makes more in this series, but they have said the rest won't be point n click. But if you're looking for another fun little (dark) point n click game, this might fit your bill.

Yeah, it's pretty good I guess. If you're thinking about picking it up, I'd say do it for the art and writing. The store page screenshots do a pretty good job showcasing that aspect of the game, so if they interest you then great, otherwise maybe don't pick it up. MechaNika's puzzles are sort of interesting too, but it's still essentially just your run of the mill point and click gameplay. Not saying the puzzles aren't neat or whatever, but they mostly just serve as a mechanic to get you out in the game world and explore (which isn't a bad thing at all). The soundtrack is alright too, but again, it's not really that special. It helps certain areas set the atmosphere, but beyond that it's not really that memorable.\n\nMy only notable gripe with this game is that the story doesn't exactly feel finished despite not it *definitely* not ending on a cliffhanger. The devs have talked in the discussion forums about making another game in the same world, so if having a full fledged condensed story also matters to you, maybe wait a bit on this series.

not a bad game at all to be honest! i did enjoy it... was kinda funny too... the only thing i wish the devs added is that u can run every where including houses...

other than that, good game and suitable with the price tag. ( i got mine off a bundle)

i do recommend it
It freaked me out a lot and at times. I'd just ask Nika what are you doing" and she would just stand there like :)"
♥ I love this game ♥\nThe only negativ thing about is that it's to short.

I always stuck playing point and click game because mostly the gameplay (and the logic) doesn't make sense to me. But not in this short game. The point I like about MechaNika is the guidance system and some alternative options to answer the puzzle or obstacle.\nI also like the story about 7 years old girl, Nika, who want to remove anything that is not awesome. Her comitment is defined in mechanika manifesto. I think she has enough reason to do so and the game successfully provide it to player. From Nika perspective this episode objective is to build a mechannics called MechaNika as a tool to make the manifesto happen.

[ Fun: 7 | Plot: 7 | CTRL: 6 | GFX: 7 | SFX: 6 | Stable: Y ] [ A Solid 7/10 ]

+ Charmingly Lo-Fi art style brimming with character
+ Amusingly off beat conversations
+ A semi-alcoholic 7 year old heroine is amusingly
+ South Parkesque ideas of childish innocence

~ Long winded tutorial that states the obvious
~ Handwritten text somewhat awkward to read
~ Rare glitches and conversation bugs

- Pretty short.. but its a Point n Click
- Long grind for steam cards (much longer than the gameplay lasts)

I love dark humor and this game had so much of it!  More importantly, I had a lot of fun playing this game.

Summary: Nika is a kick-♥♥♥ 7 year-old who drinks cognac and wants to destroy and eliminate everything in the world that she doesn't like by building a killing machine called MechaNika.  Your job is to help her gather the parts.

Pros:+ Puzzles easy enough that you're not scratching your head and wandering around for hours, but challenging enough to be satisfying.
+ Cute graphics
+ Great characters/storyline
+ Easy achievements

Cons:- Pretty short game play.  Finished the main storyline in 2.5 hours, but the game is still well-worth the $$.
This game is adorable.\nIt has some really hilarious references in the game and some pretty dirty stuff in there too. This game was really easy to play and it isn't that long of a game.
It freaked me out a lot and at times. I'd just ask Nika what are you doing" and she would just stand there like :)"

MechaNika advertises itself as a light-hearted, all-ages-friendly, short little game, and thematically, that's pretty accurate; it's hard not to have fun with this game, its simply but comically well-done artstyle, and its many references to contemporary internet culture. Players will quickly find, however, the very blatant adult elements that make this game inadvisable for exposure to its seemingly intended market audience.\n\nThe protagonist is a 7-year old girl fed up with her environment, and determined to make use of her extensive knowledge of engineering to put an end to everything not awesome. Since this is essentially any introverted child's fantasy when things aren't going their way, the game is worth a playthrough by any who've experienced similar feels as a kid.

not a bad game at all to be honest! i did enjoy it... was kinda funny too... the only thing i wish the devs added is that u can run every where including houses...

other than that, good game and suitable with the price tag. ( i got mine off a bundle)

i do recommend it

I got the Hidden Gems bundle because I was interested in this game. I've always liked point n click adventure games, as I played a lot of them, such as the Reincarnation series, back in the day on websites like NewGrounds. If you're looking for a long game like Deponia, this isn't it. This is more akin to those previously-mentioned games on NewGrounds and Kongregate.

MechaNika is about a young girl who has a pretty rough life. Your quest is to find parts to destroy everything she hates, basically. If you get stuck, you can get wasted and she'll give you a hint. There's a lot of fun little quirks in the game that you can interact with, that may or may not actually impact the story. You can complete most of it in any order you please.

I got it for $2.99 and I feel it was worth my money. If you want a more complete story, you might wait until MangoProtocol makes more in this series, but they have said the rest won't be point n click. But if you're looking for another fun little (dark) point n click game, this might fit your bill.

Yeah, it's pretty good I guess. If you're thinking about picking it up, I'd say do it for the art and writing. The store page screenshots do a pretty good job showcasing that aspect of the game, so if they interest you then great, otherwise maybe don't pick it up. MechaNika's puzzles are sort of interesting too, but it's still essentially just your run of the mill point and click gameplay. Not saying the puzzles aren't neat or whatever, but they mostly just serve as a mechanic to get you out in the game world and explore (which isn't a bad thing at all). The soundtrack is alright too, but again, it's not really that special. It helps certain areas set the atmosphere, but beyond that it's not really that memorable.\n\nMy only notable gripe with this game is that the story doesn't exactly feel finished despite not it *definitely* not ending on a cliffhanger. The devs have talked in the discussion forums about making another game in the same world, so if having a full fledged condensed story also matters to you, maybe wait a bit on this series.

Don't let the cute art style fool you, this game is not for kids, what with the dark comedy and (brief) depictions of gore and nudity. This is first and foremost a point-and-click game for adults.

7-year-old Nika Allen is a child prodigy of sorts, being quite the tinkerer with electronics and mechanical devices. She is also more mature than her age, knowing a lot more about the world than the usual 7-year-old girl. She drinks a concoction of cognac and cocoa (underage drinking, ahoy!) to inspire herself and help her 'see things clearer'. Her goal? To create a giant mech to destroy all the things 'that aren't awesome' and to eventually 'take over the world'. Hoo boy, don't get on this little girl's bad side, let me tell you.

My only real complaint with the game is how short it is. It took me two hours to beat, and I normally hope to get twice that at the very least from a point-and-click adventure. Still, those two hours were very enjoyable, filled with solid PnC puzzle solving and plenty of dark, wacky shenanigans.

At full price, yeah, this game is certainly worth it. Still, I think you should pick this up when it is on sale, if only to feel as if you got a little more bang for your little buck.
What I thought was cute point + click adventure, turned out to be a bit dark mecha building journey in order to wreck the world.
Very interesting game. Fantab references and great play through!

It's a fun game to play once or twice for the humor and story. The game is colorful and the characters range from odd, to funny, to downright awkward (I'm talking about you, tranny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥).

Overall; a whimsical game that can give at least a couple hours of fun and maybe more  if you try to get all the achievements or complete the game using alternative parts.

7/10

I don't think this game is very popular, and that's sad because it's such a great game. It's a very funny and light game and the only thing I think should change is to make it longer. If you want a short, sweet game to make you laugh out loud, then this is the game for you.

MechaNika is a witty point and click game that I was able to complete in 2 hours. The graphics are simple but the dark humor somehow syncs with it and make the game very enjoyable. The only problem I had with the game was that the text was difficult to read, at least to me. If you're sitting around home for a few hours and need something to do, MechaNika is the something to do.

short game with extremely adorable and lovable characters, i love the design and creativity of it all. also like the little references poking fun at things like construction workers or religions. soundtrack is neat too. the puzzles are challenging and you should try to remember everything you come across in the game, hints are pretty common and you might need to do a whole lot just to get one part for mechanika.\n\noh and despite how cute and childish this game looks, it is most definitely *at least* for teens

Cute, short (I cleared it in under 2.5 hours) point-and-click adventure featuring a 7-year-old girl and the crap-sack world she lives in.  The gameplay does suffer from having an interface obviously meant for tablets - click for the menu, click again to choose, etc) and a few puzzles are needlessly specific, but the story's fun and there are plenty of interesting charactes.

EPIC GAME! for how little this game costs, just get it NOW, it's short, you can finish it in around
3 hours but this game has amazing characters, tons of charm and a super cute art style!

The story of my life in game form

I don't really play these kinds of point an click games, but MechaNika was pretty fun. Bought it on sale and played it.

Pros:
Interesting characters and a funny short story involving Nika. You get to interact with a bunch of stuff and see all the funny reactions. Has a a pretty cool art and design and you can also change the subtitle format in the options menu to make it easier to read.

Cons:
It is kinda short, took me four hours to complete it (I took my time looking around). Has little replay value but you can replay it to check out different interactions and get all the acheivements.

Buy it, it is kinda cheap and a pretty fun game with a good narrative.
cute game i love it. lots of easter eggs :D
